raw_text:
Newest EU members underpin growth
 
 The European Union's newest members will bolster Europe's economic growth in 2005, according to a new report.
 
 The eight central European states which joined the EU last year will see 4.6% growth, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) said. In contrast, the 12 Euro zone countries will put in a "lacklustre" performance, generating growth of only 1.8%. The global economy will slow in 2005, the UNECE forecasts, due to widespread weakness in consumer demand.
 
 It warned that growth could also be threatened by attempts to reduce the United States' huge current account deficit which, in turn, might lead to significant volatility in exchange rates.
 
 UNECE is forecasting average economic growth of 2.2% across the European Union in 2005. However, total output across the Euro zone is forecast to fall in 2004 from 1.9% to 1.8%. This is due largely to the faltering German economy, which shrank 0.2% in the last quarter of 2004. On Monday, Germany's BdB private banks association said the German economy would struggle to meet its 1.4% growth target in 2005.
 
 Separately, the Bundesbank warned that Germany's efforts to reduce its budget deficit below 3% of GDP presented "huge risks" given that headline economic growth was set to fall below 1% this year. Publishing its 2005 economic survey, the UNECE said central European countries such as the Czech Republic and Slovenia would provide the backbone of the continent's growth. Smaller nations such as Cyprus, Ireland and Malta would also be among the continent's best performing economies this year, it said. The UK economy, on the other hand, is expected to slow in 2005, with growth falling from 3.2% last year to 2.5%.
 
 Consumer demand will remain fragile in many of Europe's largest countries and economies will be mostly driven by growth in exports. "In view of the fragility of factors of domestic growth and the dampening effects of the stronger euro on domestic economic activity and inflation, monetary policy in the euro area is likely to continue to 'wait and see', the organisation said in its report. Global economic growth is expected to fall from 5% in 2004 to 4.25% despite the continued strength of the Chinese and US economies. The UNECE warned that attempts to bring about a controlled reduction in the US current account deficit could cause difficulties. "The orderly reversal of the deficit is a major challenge for policy makers in both the United States and other economies," it noted.
llama3.2:1b: Newest EU members will grow 4.6% while Euro zone countries will grow 1.8%.
The global economy is expected to slow due to weak consumer demand, with growth threatened by US budget deficit efforts.
Central European countries will be strong performers.

The global economy is forecasted to slow due to weak consumer demand, and Germany's economy is expected to struggle with a 0.2% decline in the last quarter of 2004.

Growth will be slowed by weakening consumer demand and attempts to reduce US current account deficit.
Central European nations like the Czech Republic and Slovenia are expected to drive EU growth, with smaller nations like Cyprus, Ireland, and Malta also performing well.
UK economy is projected to slow down, and global economic growth is expected to fall from 5% in 2004 to 4.25% in 2005.
qwen2.5:0.5b: EU newest members boost growth, but potential risks from US deficit efforts remain.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Eight new EU members will boost 2005 economic growth by 4.6%, while Euro zone countries face sluggish 1.8% performance, according to UN report.
Central European nations will drive Europe's recovery, but Germany struggles with weak economy.
qwen2.5:3b: Newest EU members will bolster Europe's economic growth in 2005, with an estimated 4.6% growth expected from eight central European states joining last year.
The Eurozone, however, is forecast to grow only 1.8%.
UNECE predicts average EU growth of 2.2% in 2005, but a decline in the euro zone to 1.8%.
Growth could be threatened by US efforts to reduce its current account deficit and associated exchange rate volatility.
Central European countries like Czech Republic and Slovenia will drive growth, while smaller nations such as Cyprus, Ireland, and Malta are expected to perform well.
The UK economy is set to slow from 3.2% last year to 2.5%.
Consumer demand remains fragile in major countries, with export-driven growth dominating the continent's economic output.
Monetary policy in the euro area is likely to remain cautious due to weak domestic factors and stronger euro affecting domestic activity and inflation.
Global growth is forecast at 4.25%, despite continued strength of Chinese and US economies, with potential difficulties from US efforts to reduce its current account deficit.
opencoder:1.5b: The European Union has been growing steadily since 2005, with the eight central European states joining on August 1st.
The UNECE predicts an average growth rate of about 4.6% across the EU, which is expected to slow in the coming years as more countries start falling into recession due to economic uncertainty.
Germany's efforts to reduce its budget deficit was a clear sign of progress.
The UNECE forecasts that Germany’s target for GDP growth will fall from below 1% this year to about 2.2%, similar to what it predicted in 2004.

The UNECE said that central European countries such as the Czech Republic and Slovenia would provide the backbone of the continent's growth, while smaller economies like Cyprus, Ireland and Malta remain under their respective policies.
In terms of consumer demand, Europe's economies are expected to continue growing well, with exports remaining on track.
However, the UK economy is forecasting a decline in its GDP growth due to a strong fiscal uncertainty affecting the US economy.
The UNECE said that the UK's policy on fiscal policy remains "wait and see".
smollm:1.7b: The EU's newest members will boost Europe's economic growth in 2005, according to a new report from the UNECE.
The eight central European states which joined the EU last year will see 4.6% growth, while the 12 Euro zone countries will put in a "lackluster" performance, generating growth of only 1.8%.
The global economy will slow in 2005 due to widespread weakness in consumer demand.
The UNECE warned that growth could also be threatened by attempts to reduce the United States' huge current account deficit which, in turn, might lead to significant volatility in exchange rates.
Separately, the Bundesbank warned that Germany's efforts to reduce its budget deficit below 3% of GDP presented "huge risks" given that headline economic growth was set to fall below 1% this year.
Publishing its 2005 economic survey, the UNECE said central European countries such as the Czech Republic and Slovenia would provide the backbone of the continent's growth.
Smaller nations such as Cyprus, Ireland and Malta would also be among the continent's best performing economies this year, it said.
The UK economy, on the other hand, is expected to slow in 2005, with growth falling from 3.2% last year to 2.5%.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The EU's newest members are expected to bolster Europe's economy in 2005, according to UNECO's report, with eight member states projected to grow at around 4.6% and the Eurozone countries showing mixed results.
Germany, one of the Eurozone nations, will have a weaker performance due to its economic challenges.
The overall EU growth is forecasted at 2.2%, mainly driven by strong European economies except for Germany's struggles.
UNECO warns that attempts to reduce the US current account deficit could face economic challenges.
tinyllama:1.1b: Newest EU members will contribute to Europe's economic growth in 2005, with a growth rate of 4.6%, according to UNESCO's latest Economic Outlook report.
In contrast, the 12 Eurozone countries will have a performance that falls short compared to the United States, resulting in significant volatility in exchange rates and consumer demand.
According to UNECE, total output across Europe is expected to fall in 2004 from 1.9% to 1.8%.
The report predicts that global economic growth will drop from 5% in 2004 to 4.25%, despite the continued strength of China and US economies.

Policy-makers must remain cautious as global economic growth is expected to be controlled by policy efforts to bring about a controlled reduction in the US current account deficit, which could cause challenges for other economies.
tinydolphin:1.1b: According to a new report, the eight Central European countries that joined the EU last year will contribute 4.6% growth to the overall European economy in 2005, while the 12 Eurozone countries' combined output will decrease by 1.8%.

The global economy is expected to slow down due to reduced consumer demand in many of Europe's largest countries and economies, with growth in 2005 projected at 2.2%, compared to an average of 3.4% last year.

The European Union forecasts 2.2% average growth for 2005, but Germany's economy is expected to struggle, with small countries such as Czech Republic, Slovenia, Cyprus, Ireland, and Malta projected to perform well.
UK GDP is set to decrease from 3.2% to 2.5%.
Stronger euro will dampen domestic economic activity, while the US current account deficit reduction could cause currency volatility.

In contrast, the 12 Euro zone countries will see only 1.8% growth, contributing to an overall EU growth forecast of 2.2%.
The global economy is expected to slow due to weak consumer demand, and efforts to reduce the U.S. current account deficit could cause exchange rate volatility.
Germany's struggling economy is a key factor in the Euro zone's weak performance, with its growth forecast below 1% and concerns over its budget deficit.
Central European nations like the Czech Republic and Slovenia will be key drivers of growth, while smaller nations such as Cyprus, Ireland, and Malta will also perform well.
The UK economy is expected to slow from 3.2% to 2.5%.
Consumer demand remains fragile, with exports driving growth.
Global economic growth is projected to decline from 5% in 2004 to 4.25%, despite strong performances from China and the U.S.
The UNECE warned that managing the U.S. deficit reduction poses a major challenge for policymakers worldwide.
stablelm2:1.6b: Newest EU members will contribute to Europe's economic growth with an 4.6% increase, while Euro zone countries perform lacklusterly with only 1.8%.
Global economy growth slows due to weak consumer demand.
The UNECE forecasts average growth of 2.2% for the European Union in 5 years but total output in the Euro area falls from 1.9% to 1.8%, mainly due to Germany's faltering economy.
Central European countries will drive growth, with smaller nations such , Cyprus, Ireland, and Malta, among others.
The UK is expected to slow to 2.5%.
Challenges remain for policy makers in managing the US current account deficit, which could cause volatility in exchange rates.
granite3.1-dense:2b: In 2005, new EU members—the eight central European states—are projected to drive Europe's economic growth at 4.6%.
The remaining Euro zone countries will experience a more modest 1.8% growth.
The global economy is anticipated to slow due to diminished consumer demand and potential exchange rate volatility from efforts to mitigate the US current account deficit.
UNECE forecasts an average EU growth of 2.2%, with Euro zone output projected to decline from 1.9% in 2004 to 1.8%.
This decline is primarily attributed to Germany's weak economy, which shrank by 0.2% in Q4 2004 and faces difficulties meeting its 1.4% growth target for 2005.
The Czech Republic, Slovenia, Cyprus, Ireland, and Malta are expected to be among the best-performing European economies.
The UK's growth will slow from 3.2% in 2004 to 2.5%.
Monetary policy in the Euro area is likely to remain cautious due to fragile domestic growth factors and inflationary pressures stemming from a stronger euro.
Global economic growth is expected to drop from 5% in 2004 to 4.25%, with efforts to reduce the US current account deficit posing challenges for policy makers.
